citation.article-title: Acetomicrobium flavidum, gen. nov., sp. nov., a thermophilic, anaerobic bacterium from sewage sludge, forming acetate, CO2 and H2 from glucose.

p.s: Acetomicrobium (A.ce'to.mi.cro'bi.um. L.n. acetum vinegar; Gr. adj. mikros small; Gr. n. bios life; M. L. n. microbium a small living being, a microbe; M. L., acetomicrobium a microorganism producing acetic acid.
Straight tapered rods, ca. 0.8 μm by 2-3 μm, occurring mostly in pairs or short chains.
Murein (peptidolycan) contains meso-diaminopimelic acid (m-A2mp direct type; variation Alϒ according to Schleifer and Kandler (1972)).
Motile by means of a single subpolar flagellum or a few lateral flagella.
Good growth depends on yeast extract or peptone and carbohydrate.
Starch, casein and tributyrin are hydrolysed.
Optimum growth in the thermophilic temperature range.
Catalase and cytochromes are not present.
Under an atmosphere of 80% N2 and 20% CO2, glucose is fermented to 2 mol acetic acid, 2 mol CO2 and 4 mol H2.
Ethanol, lactate, formate, succinate or other volatile acids are not formed from hexoses.
Small amounts of volatile acids, for the instance propionic acid, may only be formed from complex substrates, e.g. yeast extract, peptone, etc.
G + C content of DNA is ca. 47 mol %. (Only one species known as yet.)
